11687557.review:
Rayman Legends takes what was established in Rayman Origins and improves it. The vector graphics are back and look prettier than ever, there is the addition of a sidekick as well to help you get through some levels.
There is a lot to do in this game, each level has 10 teensies to find (The little blue guys), as well as the challenge to find enough lums (The yellow flying guys) to earn the Gold trophy. There are also unlockable characters as well, collectable creatures, unlockable bonus levels from Rayman Origins (each has teensies and trophies to collect) and Time Trial levels as well. If you're a bit of a completionist like I am with these sorts of things, you'll have lots to keep you occupied. There is also the new music levels, which are very much like the chest chasing missions in Origins, completely timing based where you jump or attack in time with the music. These are excellently thought out and the timing is spot-on. These are a bit more forgiving than Origins' chest chasing missions though, having checkpoints rather than making you restart after each death.
There are downsides though, this game is a console port and at times it shows, making some actions hard to perform using keyboard if you don't have nimble fingers. It is perfectly playable with the keyboard though and supports full key remapping (Which I suggest you do, I set mine to the Origins controls and it saved me a lot of trouble), but it may be easier to play using a controller. I can't say which is better, since I've only played using keyboard, although you can play one handed using keyboard, leaving your other hand free to do other stuff like eat a sandwich or write a book. It also doesn't really have much replayability, apart from the music levels which are awesome just to play occasionally, unless you are a big Rayman fan. Plus it only works through UPlay, which is not a bad piece of software but it does make things frustrating when you just want to get right into the game.
Overall, this game is worth picking up, even at full price and the annoying DRM. Graphics are pretty and there is a lot to do. I'm really looking forward to the next game in the series,
10/10

11353579.review:
This game is fantastic.

I'm not much of a platform gamer, but I grew up loving the crazy twisted world of the earthworm jim games, and many good games in the early eras of gaming were fairly platform-ish... but basically it's not been a focus for me.

That said, this game really brought me back and drove home what a great experience the medium can provide.

It's made by a team composed largely of the people behind the legendary game "Beyond Good and Evil" - if that's not enough to make you moist, you havent played that game, or you have no soul.

It's dripping with character, and the art is wonderful and consistent, portraying a bizzare, slightly twisted but incredibly bright and joyful world, even in the darkest places. The music is phenomenal, with a wide variety of excellent tracks, including some that are reditions of songs you may be familiar with. 

What really got me was the well defined worlds and the sheer variety of gameplay mechanics. It seemed at times like every level was introducing a new mechanic, that may or may not be used in further levels - the path of the game is largely non-linear, with difficulty from level to level having little to do with its place in "order". 

It's most definately not a difficult game, it's a very easy to approach platformer, and you'll quickly learn the ins and outs of what they expect from you. Checkpoints are generally numerous, though the game does spice things up as you progress, there's even levels that have no checkpoints whatsoever and are just a long string of potential deaths - this initially was a source of frustration, but after completing my first level like this I couldnt deny that the sense of satisfaction gained by beating the whole thing flawlessly was well worth it, and I'm glad they had it.

It's quite hard to really convey what's really best about this game, and that's the experience of playing it. 

It's just... fun!

If there's a demo out, I'd reccomend giving it a go and seeing what you think. I cant imagine you not finding it worth your time and money though.


For long term enjoyment, they have 2 daily and 2 weekly challenges, that are varied in type and setting. While I dont particularily like all of the challenges, they're mostly very enjoyable - the distance based ones, where you're falling down an infinate pit, running up an infinately falling tower, or running across a seemingly infinate level are my favourites, and you'll find yourself rated based on where you stand vs everyone else playing the challenges. You can see the ghost players of other people who have played the challenge who are close to your score, see the markers where they bite it, and generally it just feels solid... 

Oh yeah, and this game seems to include all the levels from the previous game, Rayman Origins, within the game, so you get 2 games for 1!

As for negatives... hmmm... well there's one level left that I havent finished that's hard as shit, though I dont think that counts... 

Oh I've got one - there's a "creature" system, where you collect creatures occasionally when you beat a level, and they all go into a special room and once a day give out lums (the currency - which are these delightful little smiling bug things)  - and the system seems... pointless... you only get the monsters by beating levels, so you've basically beaten the game when you get them all, and the amount of lums they give is negligible compared to even just doing a normal level or challenge. 

Also the large number of alternate skins for barabara, the female character, are... a bit weird if not downright creepy or offensive at times. Barabara is the character I played as most due to the incredible character design, she's just brimming with a joyful michevious character that really fits the game, and she swings a mean axe... and rayman's kind of silly. But every world you enter has 2 alternate skins for barbara - the first one's pretty tame, but from then on it gets... odd.... There's barabara's that are sexualized (pronounced curves and cleavage) in appearance, and weirder still, when you die in this game you expand and then pop like a baloon - barbara's regular death is fairly normal... but there's 2 skins for her where you get a weirdass panty shot when she dies... it's... weird, man.

But whatever, lets just blame it on them being french canadian. The game is absolutely phenomenal and any negatives I've encoutered, which are few, are greatly balanced out by the awesome.

So yeah, try demo, get game, enjoy.

11298017.review:
When it comes to 2D platformers, Ubisoft has absolutely nailed everything; the controls, visuals, music, and everything else are top-notch in Rayman Legends. This game follows closely behind the formula of Rayman Origins. However, the phrase "If it ain't broken, don't fix it" really fits here. Rayman Legends takes what Origins did and refines it. There are noticeable improvements in some areas, and lots of minor gripes I had with Origins have been addressed in Legends. There are some  new creative level design ideas and elements that really helped set this game apart.

This game is every bit as charming and fun as its predecessor. Both Rayman Origins and Legends make up some of the most creative, fun, and charming 2D platforming you'll ever get to experience. I highly recommend Rayman Legends to anyone who's enjoyed even a single 2D Mario game, or past 2D Rayman games.

11297763.review:
Great casual platformer, would reccomend!

The Good:
+Fun music, happy atmosphere
+Goofy characters and situations
+Each level feels unique and most have their own little gimmick
+Not too hard, and not too easy, almost no penalty for death
+Gameplay is fun and engaging
+Each world ends in a ridiculously fun music level

The Bad:
-Uplay (Its not too bad but I mean, c'mon there is no need for this crap)
-The "hidden" areas are not very hidden and start to be "hidden" in the same ways
-Some of the bosses are frustratingly unfun.

11296403.review:
Após alguns anos de sumiço que sucederam Rayman Raving Rabbids (que não foi tão bem recebido pela crítica), o ressurgimento do Rayman com o reboot de 2011 Rayman Origins deu um baita gás ao gênero plataforma 2D, o qual, ao meu ver, parece ter sido deixado de lado nos últimos tempos. Não diferente, Rayman Legends retoma a boa e velha fórmula dos plataformas 2D, para a alegria dos apreciadores do gênero e conhecimento para os que não estão familiarizados, e retorna com o melhor do Origins, desta vez mais polido e com mais conteúdo.

Começando pela história, o jogo apresenta uma justificativa para os eventos ao invés de uma história de fato, não havendo complexidade nesse aspecto. O que acontece é que cinco teensies malignos surgem, sequestram uma quantidade absurda de teensies bons (“só” 700) e começam a tocar o terror no mundo dos heróis. A partir dessa premissa, Rayman e os vários outros personagens (Globox, os teensies jogáveis e as princesas que precisam ser libertadas) devem livrar a Clareira dos Sonhos dos malvados e resgatar essa população de teensies sequestrados.

As fases são divididas em pinturas (mais ou menos como acontece no Super Mario 64), existindo seis grandes pinturas principais temáticas (como se fossem “mundos”) que, com exceção da última - que é especial -, englobam em torno de 15 fases cada uma, sendo todas acessadas a partir das galerias do jogo. Juntamente com as pinturas principais (que somam pouco mais de 80 no total), o jogo ainda traz de volta 40 fases do Rayman Origins adaptadas para o Legends. Como se não bastassem mais de 100 fases, a Ubisoft disponibiliza semanal e diariamente desafios para os jogadores em seus servidores, coisas como coletar o máximo possível de lums num determinado período de tempo ou o quão longe o jogador consegue ir numa fase, e compara os seus resultados com os de jogadores ao redor do mundo. Com o tempo pode começar a ficar meio repetitivo, mas é divertido de qualquer forma. Ou seja, tem conteúdo pra caramba pra se jogar.

Nos gráficos, a engine Ubi Art Framework foi aprimorada e traz gráficos muito mais sólidos, com uma integração 2D-3D muito bem feita: embora seja um jogo essencialmente 2D, o cenário e os personagens são vivos e dinâmicos e você tem perfeita noção do que se passa em todos os níveis e dimensões do cenário. O jogo não se limita somente ao que está no caminho dos personagens, os detalhes do fundo e da frente tornam todos os cenários riquíssimos em detalhes. Além disso, é um jogo extremamente colorido e bonito de se ver.

A trilha sonora tem um lugar especial na análise (e no meu coração). Ela é simplesmente EXCEPCIONAL, um grande trabalho feito por Christophe Héral e Billy Martin. Cada mundo tem uma trilha sonora bastante específica para o seu tema, com o qual combina impecavelmente, e transita entre diferentes estilos que cativam o jogador.

Devo abrir um parágrafo aqui pra falar especialmente das seis fases musicais, nas quais a progressão do jogador combina perfeitamente com a música de fundo em cada ação e movimento, dos pulos aos ataques. Das seis músicas, quatro são inspiradas em músicas famosas e foram muito bem adaptadas para o jogo; as outras duas são de autoria da Ubisoft e não ficam atrás em termos de qualidade. Parece um mix de Guitar Hero com plataforma, é espetacular. Você tem vontade de jogar cada uma delas várias e várias vezes (eu mesmo jogo praticamente todas sempre que inicio o jogo). E depois de resgatar 400 teensies ainda tem uma surpresa para os gamers da velha guarda.

O gameplay é ótimo. Existem quatro personagens básicos (Rayman, Globox, Bárbara e um Teensie) e muitos outros desbloqueáveis (que na realidade são os modelos básicos com alguma variação no visual) com os lums coletados. Os controles respondem super bem, os movimentos de todos os personagens são muito articulados e nada parece “travado”. A única sensação que eu tenho às vezes é de que o controle pode ser “escorregadio”, principalmente quando se tenta disparar na corrida em um espaço pequeno e o personagem vai parar além de onde deveria, o que pode provocar umas mortes indesejadas, mas isso deve ser impressão minha e não atrapalha de forma alguma na jogatina. Uma das impressões que eu tive é que TUDO nesse jogo pode ser esmurrado, chutado ou tomar qualquer tipo de porrada e gerar alguma resposta engraçada, principalmente no cooperativo, que pode facilmente se tornar uma sessão de UFC entre os jogadores. 

Falando em Multiplayer, este é o único aspecto negativo do jogo. Rayman Legends tem suporte apenas para cooperativo LOCAL de até quatro jogadores, ou seja, nada de jogar pela internet com o coleguinha que está longe, o que eu acho uma pena e um grande desperdício de diversão. Platformers são muito divertidos no sofá com os amigos, mas isso não deveria excluir a possibilidade de se jogar à distância. O cooperativo do jogo é muito divertido, porém pode facilmente se transformar em caos na Terra, pois juntar quatro indivíduos num cenário pode atrapalhar um pouco nos objetivos (principalmente se for considerar que os players podem se espancar), um “problema” que não é exclusivo do Rayman Legends e pode acontecer com qualquer plataformer cooperativo. Independentemente da bagunça, um cooperativo online seria muito bem vindo.

O jogo não é particularmente difícil (com exceção das fases de Invasão, as quais precisam ser terminadas em menos de 40 segundos para libertar todos os teensies, e que me renderam vários tapas na perna). O jogo começa a ficar mais desafiador a partir do terceiro mundo e, mesmo assim, embora seja possível passar das fases sem frustração, a satisfação de se concluir uma fase é imensa, e a vontade de passar por ela novamente é constante.

Enfim, somando-se a música ótima, os gráficos lindos, o gameplay fluido e os cenários vívidos, Rayman Legends parece um grande organismo bastante vivo, sempre se mexendo, com cores fortes, coisas acontecendo por todos os lados, sons para tudo que acontece e que prende a atenção do jogador. Foi um dos poucos jogos que me fez escancarar um sorrisão enquanto jogava, e cada fase eu achava a melhor até eu jogar a próxima. É um marco no gênero plataforma, inspirado nos melhores clássicos e certamente um clássico contemporâneo, um prato cheio para quem cresceu jogando jogos do mesmo estilo e até para quem está começando agora. Sem a menor dúvida, um dos melhores jogos que já joguei na vida e, na minha singela opinião, a Ubisoft fez o plataformer perfeito, ou senão algo muito próximo disso.

Rayman Legends não é um jogo para criança, nem para adultos e nem para velhos. Rayman Legends é uma obra de arte que independe de idade para ser apreciada, e deve ser apreciada por todos.

11275649.review:
Rayman Legends est un jeu de plateforme 2D développé par Ubisoft et qui fait office de "suite" à Rayman Origins, épisode qui a essentiellement servi de reboot à la franchise et de démo technique plutôt complète au moteur Ubi Art, qui propose ici des graphismes chatoyants tendant allègrement vers le cartoon. Pour les amateurs de TL;DR, voici ce que j'en pense : si vous avez aimé Rayman Origins, vous adorerez Rayman Legends. Maintenant pour celles et ceux qui veulent un peu plus de consistance à ma recommandation, voici un bon petit pavé bien riche en analyse.

Rayman Legends reprend grosso modo les éléments de plateforme conçus dans Rayman Origins, à ceci près que votre progression dans le déblocage des niveaux ne se fait plus sur une sorte de mappe-monde relativement simpliste, mais par le biais de tableaux et de sous-tableaux (respectivement mondes et niveaux), dont certains ne se débloqueront qu'en fonction de votre progression dans les niveaux ou du nombre de Ptizètres que vous aurez sauvé. Rien de bien méchant tout de même, la courbe de difficulté entre les niveaux et les mondes reste globalement bien dosée et les premiers niveaux d'un monde ne vous poseront que très peu de problème. Ce point est d'autant plus appréciable que cette courbe reste, d'après mon ressenti, beaucoup moins abrupte que Rayman Origins, qui avait bien fini par m'agacer sur les derniers niveaux.

Toutefois, le jeu propose aussi son lot de défis, et vous aurez l'occasion de mourir souvent, essentiellement sur un passage très précis d'un niveau qui demandera parfois un peu de dextérité, et d'autres fois l'acquisition d'un pattern précis digne d'un die and retry : le 100% (les Ptizètres, le nombre de Lums à récolter) ne vous sera jamais totalement acquis et il faudra faire preuve d'un peu de dextérité et d'observation pour compléter un niveau parfaitement. D'autre part, vous aurez la possibilité de participer à des défis régulièrement mis à jour : récupérer un nombre de Lums en un temps record, aller le plus loin possible dans un niveau renouvelé, atteindre la fin d'un niveau le plus vite possible... ce sont des activités qui, en plus de mettre à l'épreuve votre dextérité, vous permet de gagner des Lums supplémentaires en fonction de votre performance... Et des Lums, vous en aurez besoin pour débloquer tous les skins disponibles pour votre personnage !

Une bonne évaluation ne serait pas bonne s'il n'y avait pas des points négatifs à soulever. Et je dois admettre qu'il en existe quelques uns qui peuvent être rédhibitoires pour certains d'entre vous. Premier point négatif : UPlay. Oui, malheureusement, il faudra s'y faire, si vous voulez jouer à un jeu Ubisoft récent sur PC, il faudra vous infliger cette merde. Pour vous consoler, dites-vous que d'autres personnes doivent se taper Origin pour jouer à leur jeu.... Et deuxième point négatif, la maniabilité que je trouve particulièrement étrange dans ce jeu (et dans Origins d'ailleurs) : étant plutôt habitué à jouer à des jeux de plateformes avec des personnages répondant au doigt et à l'oeil (et avec notamment des nuanciers de saut précis et instinctifs), je ne me suis jamais complètement adapté au comportement de Rayman, notamment lors des attaques sautées (il s'arrête littéralement en plein milieu d'une course) ou sur les sauts eux-mêmes (pas mal de mes morts sont dues à des sauts qui s'avéraient trop courts ou trop longs compte tenu de la vitesse de course de mon personnage).

Si vous passez outre ces deux principaux défauts, vous trouverez un jeu complet, avec une très bonne courbe de difficulté et doté d'une réalisation solide et réussie.

11275578.review: Besides having to use another client (Uplay) after starting the game, the game itself is probably one of the most engrossing 2D platformers that I have ever played. Most of the stages are incredibly fun and amazingly drawn. The difficulty level may not be as difficult as origins but the fluidity of the levels makes up for it. Tons of unlockables and daily/weekly challenges invite replayability and the little details the developers put in the game (unique animations where you roll as you land and crouch at the same time, etc.) really show. If you ever encounter this game during a steam sale, definitely consider buying it.

11271690.review:
Sehr, sehr tolles Spiel! Ich habe bereits den Vorgänger "Rayman: Origins" auf der Xbox 360 zu 100% durchgespielt. Zu diesem Teil hier bleibt mir nur eines zu sagen: Tolles Spiel! Ich liebe die Grafik (im Vorgänger auch schon), die Level sind abwechslungsreich und es gibt eine Menge zu erledigen. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad steigt human an und wird immer schwerer. Jedoch ist keines der Level unmöglich! Man kann in jedem Level einen Bronze-, Silber- oder Goldpokal erreichen und Kleinlinge sammeln, die überall versteckt sind (je nach Level gilt es 3 oder 10 Kleinlinge zu sammeln)! Manche verstecke sind sehr mies, aber wenn man sich ein wenig anstrengt bekommt man sie alle raus.

Alles was im Vorgänger schon super war haben sie hier noch mehr verbessert! Ich konnte bisher keine Bugs/Fehler entdecken, keine Ruckler oder ähnliches. Kann dieses Spiel nur jedem empfehlen, schlagt zu!

11251070.review:
Más y mejor Rayman. ¿Qué más agregar a Rayman Legends?

Si jugaron Rayman Origins, esta nueva entrega no los va a defraudar. Y si no lo jugaron, aprovechen que incluye en [i]Back To Origins[/i], varios de sus niveles remasterizados.
Sin duda lo mejor son los niveles rítmicos, con melodías únicas, incluso en 8-bit. Las últimas pantallas son un delirio increíble.
Además podemos jugarlo completo junto a 3 micos más (como en Origins). Haciendo más graciosa la travesía. El juego colaborativo por momentos puede facilitarnos el pasar de un nivel a otro, pero también complicarnos. Más que nada en ciertos niveles de velocidad y coordinación de movimientos.
No se puede parar hasta conseguir todos los logros. Lástima que requiere UPlay y dichos logros se ven reflejados solamente ahí.

11093891.review:
As a true Rayman fan, who owns every single one of the Rayman games; I couldn't miss this one in my list. 

Rayman Legends stays (just like Origins) in the old settings of '2D' gaming and is a nice reminder of the old days. The levels are well designed and just as lovely to play. The music varies from Orchestral to Rock, and the 'music' levels will surely get a smile on your face.  

Besides the main games, you can also win in-game prizes, such as levels in the worlds of Origins, 'creatures' that give you free lums and much more.

Though the game is originally designed for kids, it is seriously difficult to play. Some levels are never saved inbetween and you seriously have to get it all through in one go... making even me, a rather often playing gamer, really frustrated. 

Besides all that the harder levels, are seriously HARD.

I, myself, play on the keyboard, and the 'W' for help and 'S' to hit, arent always as ideal as thought by the designers. Fortunately you can change that in the settings. 

It might sound all really intense, but I would really recommend the game. It's well worth it's money in both time to play and the in-game content (without paying for a DLC).

Level design is superb, controls are tight, and those music levels are AMAZING! You can beat up your friends while standing around doing nothing. Plus Kung Foot alone is worth it :D

11077729.review:
I think I've played this game sufficient enough to write a review for it. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys platformers, because in all my years, this has to be one of the best I've ever played. 

There are tons of extremely fun and challenging levels, multitudes of goodies to unlock (including more levels and more characters to use) and daily and weekly challenges for you to run.

All in all this game will keep you busy, it also doesn't hurt that the game looks beautiful, and plays extremely well. 

I just don't think you'll find a better platformer on PC currently. Most of the best are on consoles, but at least we have this one to enjoy. Pick it up!

11062270.review:
Game has great art and has some nice music but has some serious problems which render it a frustrating and un-fun experience. 

The gameplay mechanics are inconstant and lack depth. Simple things like not being able to do a charge attack upwards shows how little polish the game has. The running attack mechanic is poorly designed and flings you forward causing you to lose the ability to accurately land after a run attack. You can't "hang" off ledges, which means you will spend a lot of time accidentally running off cliffs when you simply meant to get close to the edge.

Collecting random garbage is NOT fun. The game ranks you based on how many fairies and mini guys you grab but at no point do you feel rewarded for collecting these things. The fairies are ONLY used to unlock characters which don't have any different abilities or anything unique about them. The mini guys that you find unlock levels but having to find 10 of them per level makes the task feel like a chore instead of a game. Overall you spend the majority of your time collecting items that serve little purpose.

Enemies? What enemies? The enemies in this game are WAY too easy. It is almost impossible to die from them as they don't attack back, rarely move, and have such a short range of attack. The game would be more fun if you didn't have an attack button and actually had to land on the enemies heads, at least this would give them a shred of difficulty.

The saving in this game is absolute trash. Did you just spend 10 minutes collecting all the random garbage in an area. Well you better not die because if you do you will have to collect all of it again. In almost every other modern platformer I have played the things you collect are saved but you are returned to an earlier checkpoint. Making you go back and have to recollect every item is terrible design. Not to mention replaying the music over and over which is annoying to say the least.

90% of the levels are a complete bore and lack creativity.  Each world introduces some new level mechanic but none of these mechanics are really "fun". Flying = boring. Sneaking = boring. Hitting Y to move some element in the level = oh god so boring. Compare this game to any other platformer and you will see more creativity in one level than you would in this entire game. 

Overall the game can be summed with two words "not fun". It doesn't hold a candle to  Braid, Super Mario, Little Big Planet and many other modern platformers.  It is a step back in patforming and I am surprised that people have given it such high praise.

Viele finden Rayman Legends besser als den Vorgänger. Dem stimme ich zu, die auch so schon wunderschöne Grafik wurde duch eine Art Cel-Shading-Effekt nochmal so richtig aufgebohrt. Viele Stellen sind fairer, das Scorehunting ist durch die vielen Checkpoints äußerst komfortabel. Die akustische Untermalung? Eine Bombe. Super lebhafte Soundkulisse und schöne Musikstücke. Besonders die Rhythmus-Level am Ende jeder Welt gehören zu den Highlights von Rayman Legends.

Trotzdem ist Legends nicht das perfekte Rayman Jump'n'Run. Grafik, Sound, Steuerung, Umfang, Leveldesign, Secrets – alles Top! Allerdings denkt man sich trotzdem irgendwo: "Das hab ich schon mal irgendwo gesehen." Man wartet einfach zu oft auf den gewissen "A ha!"-Effekt. An die kleinen Meisterwerke Rayman 1 und 2 kommt dieses Spiel leider nicht heran.

Dennoch: 9 out of 10, would save those Teensies again.

10989959.review:
If you are looking for a PC platformer, this is a must have (even with everything we all hate about Uplay)

I wanted to fill that Super Mario Bros. hole and although it took a couple of hours to really let Rayman Legends grow on me, this is easily one of the best games I own.  The momentum is naturally different from Mario and an attack throws things off initially but a half dozen levels or so and things will start feeling pretty natural.

- Some of the best high resolution 2D art I've ever seen
- Wide variety in levels (jumping, flying, swimming, timed, stealth, boss fights, even a Rockband inspired music level)
- Non linear progression so you can do whatever you are in the mood for
- Early and frequent character unlocks (key for me, as I'm not terribly fond of the original Rayman)
- Challenge modes that make you feel like you are playing with other people work surpisingly well

10989903.review:
Partiendo de la base de que Rayman Origins fue, es y será un juego perfecto, me resulta complicado afirmar que este Rayman Legends supera a su antecesor. Sí, tiene más de todo y mejor, lo cual ya lo convierte en un juego de plataformas más que sobresaliente, pero en general carece de la sensación de redondez que sí tenía Origins.

Desde luego que los mundos y niveles nuevos de Legends, que son muchos, son la repanocha, pero después de ver la cantidad de extras innecesarios (partidos de fútbol, colecciones de bichos, rejugar niveles ya vistos en Origins, etc), uno se pregunta qué habría pasado si el esfuerzo por incluirlos se hubiese aplicado en darle una mayor profundidad y cohesión al juego en sí.

Rayman Legends es muy bueno, sí, y ese Orchestral Chaos bien vale una misa, pero da penica pensar que podría haber sido mucho mejor.

10989309.review:
O primeiro ponto e mais importante a ser tomado aqui é que você precisa do aplicativo da uplay para poder jogar este jogo. Isso é uma tática muito primitiva e desrrespeitosa com o consumidor final, pois retira o sentimento de liberdade e conforto quando se compra um jogo online.
Ok, acabou ai os pontos ruins do game. SÉRIO.
Senão fosse a opção de dois jogadores, poderia dizer que o jogo é tedioso e repetitivo. 
Mas não.
Fazia muito tempo que eu procurava um game para jogar com a minha esposa. Quem tem uma sabe, mulher adora atrapalhar sua jogatina...
Quando eu comprei o game cai na realidade:
" - NOSSA, eu nunca paguei R$ 60,00 em um jogo que não estava interessado"
Morreu aí a decepção, minha esposa joga no controle e eu no teclado, os botoes são simples, poucos e nada confusos, até mesmo para ela que tem pouca coordenação motora.
Outro ponto positivo é o humor. Tudo no jogo é engraçado, garante boas risadas e faz a gente relaxar demais. 
Mas o ápice do game é mesmo a última fase de cada mundo. Todos os mundos são tematicos e as ultimas fases de cada são fases musicais. A música acompanha o jogador num ritmo frenético. É demais.
Enfim, não posso opinar sobre o game no modo single-player. Mas posso dizer com plena certeza que muitos gamers por ai sofrem para achar bons games cooperativos como esse.
Então, se sua mulher/amigo/filho/parente quer jogar com você, Rayman Legends é o game perfeito para isso.
Compra.

10958920.review:
Oh. My. God.

This game is fantastic! I love everything about it, from the cute cartoony style, to the barely visible make-it-up-as-you-go story, to the total general bad-ass-ness of everything you do. But beware: this game is not easy. It is one of the only games I have ever rage-quit, and I am completely unable to get past Ninja Grand-Master Temple. But it doesn't matter. When replaying levels is just as fun as playing them for the first time, with new cool characters available at every turn, and with a race of creatures so cute that it will make you weep for hours (the Teensies), this game offers entertainment for all ages, forever.

And the musical maps. See the first line. They defy description. Have you ever wanted to bounce through a giant swamp, and land on the head of a giant toad, on the beat? And feel like it's you, not the game, doing that? It's just amazing.

I love this game, and would buy it again.

But beware.

Twórcy tej gry dokonali niemożliwego - sprawili, że poczułem się jakbym miał 10 lat, kiedy to zagrywałem się w takie platformówki Jazz Jackrabbit czy Kapitan Pazur. Taki powrót do przeszłości wywował na mojej twarzy szeroki uśmiech. Wszystko za sprawą tytułowego Raymana i jego ziomków. Gra z pewnością sprawi wiele radości zarówno młodym jak i tym trochę starszym graczom. Dlaczego? Bo to świetny produkt. Animacje i design poziomów stoi na najwyższym poziomie, a na dodatek poziomy są niezwykle zróżnicowane - od takich gdzie pędzimy przed siebie uciekając przed lawą, po takie gdzie najważniejsza jest precyzja. Aha, no i mamy jeszcze poziomy muzyczne, które są przejawem czystego geniuszu. Synchronizacja tego co dzieje się na planszy z odtwarzanymi dźwiękami wypadła zankomicie! Jeśli nie wierzycie to poszukacjie w sieci filmików z map Castle Rock czy Mariachi Madness, coś pięknego! Z resztą cała ścieżka audio stoi na bardzo wysokim poziomie i w połączeniu z oprawą video tworzy raj dla zmysłów gracza. Wszystko to zostało polane soczystą dawką humoru. 10/10

PS. Do grania zdecydowanie polecam pada, granie na klawiaturze odbiera sporo frajdy.

10869253.review:
I love platformer games.  They're such a nostalgia blast, taking me back to the old days where I was parked on the living room floor, 5 ft. from the TV trying master that epic double jump without falling in the hole for the 10th time in a row.  Rayman Origins came along and proved that that old school platforming action could still be viable, fun and challenging.  Now, Rayman Legends has managed to come along and actually improve on the foundation that Origins laid! 

Rayman Legends packs a ton of fun in one single package.  You have unlocks to collect, in the form of lums, characters, monsters and even old Origins levels.  You have challenging platformer action.  You have varied platformer action!  You have a great sense of humor.  You have a great art style to make it all shine.  It's really great.  

Sometimes, games of these types reach a point where the game becomes too difficult.  It makes the experience nothing but frustrating and then the fun falls off fast.  Even Origins suffered from this from time to time.  In Legends, they've managed to find a perfect balance in the difficulty.  Most maps are challenging, without becoming anger inducing.  You might have to take two or three tries and a particular jump, but the pattern will click.  These types of games can also suffer from repetition, but Legends break that up as well.  You'll find the puzzle style changing from level to level, even within the same groups, keeping the game feeling fresh and entertaining. 

Beyond all the platformer action, I'm really impressed with the style and art direction going on in the game.  The end levels in each section doing something really great in how the tie in the games music with the game play.  This really stood out when I was playing a boss level to a Rayman-esque rendition of Ram Jam's "Black Betty".  As I came to obstacles, it because clear my jumps were timed to the drum beat of the song.  As you progressed, hearing that familiar back beat, you noticed the entire level was timed to it.  I couldn't help by smile and play the level over a couple times, just to marvel at the fun of it all.  They do this on every level and it's an attention to detail that you don't see to often!  

So, should you snag Rayman Legends?  Yes.  Yes you should.  Don't even debate it.  Really, this game is worth it at any price.  Definitely bring your game pad though, I can't imagine pulling this game off with a keyboard and mouse.

Mein erstes PC-Spiel war Rayman 2, was im Gegensatz zu dem hier ein 3D Jump'n'Run war. Und seitdem war ich eigentlich Rayman Fan. Holte mir Rayman M und Rayman 3, jedoch wurde es nach dem dritten Teil leise um Rayman und als Rayman mit Raving Rabbids zurückkam war das für mich erst ne Entäuschung.

Jedoch ist mit Rayman mit Legens (bzw. eigentlich auch Origins, was teilweise in Legends überarbeitet enthalten ist) zurück. Zwar können die Figuren nicht mehr normal reden wie in 2 und 3, jedoch ist das egal, denn die nette Darstellung von Mimik und "Quasi-Sprache" reichen vollkommen aus.

Am allerbesten finde ich immer die Musiklevel am Ende. So lässt es sich "Eye of the Tiger" in einer Mariachi Version herrlich in den Leveln rumhüpfen. Wer mal auf ein witziges und vor allem sehr langes Spielvergnügen hofft, der sollte nicht nachdenken, sondern zuschlagen! Den 700 Kleinlinge werden bestimmt nicht in 30min gerettet. =D

P.S.: Dennoch vermisse ich einen eventuell "4. Teil von Rayman".

10832108.review:
This is a game of rare quality. 

Unless you've lived under a rock these past few years, you know Ubisoft rebooted the Rayman franchise in 2011 with the critically acclaimed Rayman Origins. This game saw the limbless hero of many games in my childhood return to his platformer roots. The game was visually stunning and challenging with a superb soundtrack to boot. 

And now we have Rayman Legends. This game is quite literally the logical next step for the reboot of this franchise. It still has the cartoony visuals, but this time it looks like you're watching a moving painting instead of a colourful cartoon. The level design is top notch and can be very challenging at times (which led to frustration in my case. Not that that is necessarily a bad thing as it made overcoming these obtacles that much sweeter) and oh my God is the soundtrack even better than the last one. Everything just breathes atmosphere and polish and the attential to graphical detail and the interaction between what happens on the screen and the music/sound design is nothing short of a victory in game design. Well done.

So, for a fair price you get a whole plethora of levels set in different worlds, loads of collectibles, online rankings (with daily and weekly challenges) and a host of levels from Rayman Origins with updated visuals. 

In short: best platform game in recent memory. Worth every penny.

10825004.review:
So far I got 3/6 worlds finished, not counting the Origin Worlds that you can unlock and not counting any challenges or hidden areas. This game continues where Origins left - gameplay and "story" alike. It also adds some things to the formula, like your pixie helper you can raise bridges, cut ropes and eat cake. Also you can be turned into a duck or infiltrate a James-Bondian underwater lair. So far, so Rayman.

If you played Origins, you already know the new Rayman is a splendid combination of Mario, Sonic and Rayman games in terms of Jump'n'Run, Speedrunning and Wackyness. Legends doubles the fun with perfectly speedrunnable maps, many secrets to find and even Rythm levels. The game is smooth, beautiful and has even more gorgeous soundtracks the the previous title. To the less important additions count a strange monster collecting game and ticket rubbing. 

Rayman Origins is, in my opinion, the best Jump'n'Run in history. Rayman Legends comes close, but despite the greatness of the levels, the less punishing checkpoint system and the TLC overall, I feel slightly disconnected from the overall story. You can skip worlds and levels and do them in your own order (with boss and rythm levels being an exception) and the feeling of advancement is overshadowed by the "Do whatever you please" attitude. It is probably more fitting for a Rayman game, but Legends cannot quite grasp the tone like Origins did it, where the the transition between the worlds was smooth and logical.

P.S.: James Bondian Laser Security System can be run through without you needed to stop which felt so forking awesome!

10819491.review: В своё время, сделав предварительный заказ на Rayman Legends, я получил в подарок копию Rayman Origins. Был безмерно удивлен и рад, что в наше время кто-то ещё в состоянии сделать правильный, интересный и запоминающийся платформер с примерами отличного дизайна, атмосферы и геймплея. Rayman Legends прямое продолжение, возвращающее нас в Луговину снов с новыми приключениями. Графически ничего не изменилось, игра сделана на том же фреймворке, что и предшественник, большинство моделей, персонажей, объектов, тоже оттуда. Музыка, как всегда хороша, появились даже специальные "музыкальные" уровни. Я хотел закрыть глаза, честно хотел, но... всё же общее качество игры снизилось. Чем запомнился Origins? Именно идеально выстроенными уровнями и их разнообразием, проходя которые ты с нетерпение ждал следующего. Тут же, по - настоящему оригинальным является только последний мир, а сама схема уровней стала до того прямолинейной, что люмы и пришедшие на смену электунам малютки, сами идут в руки. Наверное, поняв это, разработчик в нагрузку, дополнительно запихнул в игру практически все уровни из Origins, которые нужно пройти для полного прогресса. Сомнительное удовольствие, для игравших в оригинал. Из нововведений, кроме уменьшения порога вхождения (деградации), стоит отметить сомнительные мини-забавы для маленьких, типа сада с монстрами, по типу аналога из "Plants vs. Zombies" и местного футбола под названием "Kung Foot". Подробнее на которых останавливаться не хочется, но хочется, простите за тавтологию, пожелать свежих творческих идей товарищу Анселю. Не полноценное продолжение, но верная духу оригинала игра, достойная прохождения и восхищения, но меньше, чем первая часть.

10807955.review:
This games is misrepresented and badly advertised. 

Not only does the store page not have any clear labeling of the forced uplay instalation outside the small greyed out print at the very bottom of the screen, the games crashes on startup if you are connected to the interent. This can be avoided by disabling the LAN/WiFi connection on your PC and disconnecting yourself from the internet and then launhing the game. Releasing a game in this state is not right from any company but from the likes of a Triple-A publisher like Ubisoft this is an insult to the paying customer. 

It also cannot be played in fullscreen on 1080p monitors when using AMD graphics cards without significant adjustment either. As standard this game runs at 50hz in fullscreen 1080p forcing a black frame around the screen. This can be fixed by setting up a Custom Resolution in the AMD Catalyst Control Center. 

You can also run the game in windowed mode in which case the game is displayed correctly at 1080p and 60hz, but the game does not have an option for full screen windowed either so this also presents the game in a less than optimal maner. Again there is a fix, and again it involves the use of external applications to fix the problems created uncaring and bad developers, you need an application to firce full screen borderless windowed like "Borderless Gaming" and "Fullscreenizer".

This of course is not an issue for Nvidia users, Ubisoft are openly backed by Nvidia and their software solutions, it is only an issue for AMD graphics cards. 

This is basic stuff and the developers have made a mess of it. They have had years since the release of the game and still these issues have not been fixed. 

This game is not worth the money, clearly they are not using it to produce complete and working games. Do not buy this game.

10786807.review:
I'm all for Rayman, I'm a fan of the original Rayman on the Atari Jaguar/PSX, it was colorful, and I was a huge fan of the very difficult and challenging nature of the platformer.  I have not played any other Rayman games except the original, so I'm not sure of those leading up to this game.  The art style in this game is very vivid and colorful, just like the original, which I really like.  The music is also okay, though I was not a huge fan, that is just personal preference.  

The main "lobby" for selecting worlds and levels feels cluttered, like they just threw it together.  The movement is pretty good, my only gripe is that you can only charge your punch standing flat on the ground.  My main problems begin with level design.  They really like to use these chains/ropes which you can grab onto and slide down, but unfortunately if you even get CLOSE to anything that you can grab onto, it will auto grab whether you want to grab onto it or not, and you have to hold down and jump in order to let go.  After grabbing onto, say, a rope that you can slide on, you gain a lot of momentum almost instantly, which means if you are trying to get to something to the left, you have to let go of the rope and walk back, which, if there is an obstacle you have to jump over, you might accidentally grab onto the rope again and have to repeat this same process over and over.  It's little things like that, those which happened often enough to be annoying but weren't huge playability issues, which stacked up just enough to make the game feel awkward and tedious.

The level design isn't very interesting, every level blended together, felt pretty much the same, and left me bored very quickly.  Everything is very simple and quite easy, for the most part you can just hold down the run button and blast through all of the enemies without a second thought or ounce of difficulty.  They introduce a basic enemy right off the bat which is almost no threat at all whatsoever, I don't know how anyone could ever get hit by them.  Later on they give those enemies wooden shields, but you can just kick and one shot them just like the others, what is the point of them having shields if they are literally the same enemy and the shield does absolutely NOTHING?

Basically, I just feel like I am just playing Super Rayman Bros. Wii U.  They don't really do anything interesting to pull you in and get you addicted and wanting to play more, it felt more like a chore going through each level like a zombie hoping that the next level would be exciting (never happened).  I will say, though, that this game would probably be best to play co-op with friends and not single player.  It seems to be designed with the exact same co-op as Super Mario Bros. Wii U (and the four five or six or how many other generic mario bros. platformers Nintendo made for the Wii, not including Galaxy of course, those games were a breath of fresh air).  Easy to say that I would not recommend a game that left me wanting to quit after getting halfway through the second world.  It's not interesting, it really doesn't introduce anything new or exciting, it's just, well, a generic, unmemorable platformer.

10679947.review:
Это один из лучших платформеров на сегодняшний день. Вся суть игры нестись на другой конец мира сломя голову, пытаясь как можно точнее вписаться во внезапно возникшее перед тобой препятствие, до тех пор пока не начнут слезиться глаза от невозможности моргнуть, не начнет в пылу игры сводить пальцы и задница в каком-то неловком положении. Да, когда игра переходит в time-to-run, она превращается в ад и пусть вас не обманывает красочная картинка. Но прекрасно подобраная музыка, как бальзам на мои нервы, её можно слушать и слушать после очередного рестарта. По сложности и ужасу происходящего ей конечно далеко до Super Meat Boy, но как его лайт-версия с выдержанными канонами платформинга это его лучший вариант. 
Ужасно приятный фактор, это её реиграбильность, игра вмещает в себе как Rayman Legends, так и все наиболее яркие и запонимающиеся части Rayman Оrigins (а это несколько десятков), отполированные и качественно улучшенные уровни, [strike]есть возможность играть в... футбол? О_о [/strike] а так же набор соревновательных игр, обнавляющиеся каждый день и каждую неделю. Казалось бы, наделали рандомногенерируемых событий, бесконечных платформинговых уровней, но так приятно зайти спустя время и пройти что-то новое. И постоянно думать, что менеджеры Ubisoft работают над ней пока ты спишь.

10269802.review:
[h1]VERDICT[/h1] [b]Buy Now (9.6/10)[/b]
Completion Time: 20-25 hours
Bottom Line: "[i]This game is quite simply the best. Rayman is at it again[/i]"

[h1]PROS[/h1]
+Level Design
+Level Variety
+SO MANY LEVELS
+Really pretty
+Hilarious
+Awesome Music
+Replay Value
+The Credits

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-No Online Co-op
-Uplay integration
-The game ends

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]

This game is quite simply the best. Rayman is at it again as he traverses 80 creative and often hilarious levels to save the world from nightmares. You'll be swimming, flying, transforming and more through 8 incredibly stylish and unique worlds. With each level you will surely be trying something new, with a huge variety of gameplay mechanics involved. 

Level designs are incredibly fun and fast paced, including musical levels where your actions are synchronized with the music. While we're on this topic, the score is awesome. There is everything from tropical ukulele driven tunes to stealthy James Bond-esque ballads. Did I mention this game is really pretty? Especially the remastered throwback levels where the detail is immense.

Don't even get me started on replay value. Not only are there 120 levels to master, but in each there are plenty of collectables and secret areas. Online challenges also ensure the introduction of fresh new content EVERY DAY. Finally, the ending includes the most creative credits sequence I have ever seen. Never have credits been so much fun.

There are only two minor gripes I have with the game. There is no online multiplayer co-op, and there is Uplay integration, meaning you must create a Ubisoft account in order to start the game. Otherwise this game is absolutely brilliant.

10196404.review:
Really good platformer that shows an amazing amount of effort put forward both artistically and level designs. The music is fantastic, topped off only by having a few special levels that revolve around the music. The game is packed with a lot of fun and a lot of laughs, I love Origins and Legends is certainly a worthy sequel with a lot of charm to it. 

Other platformers certainly seem to have gotten lazy with their games, where one would struggle to know which one is which if they didnt' see the title screen. This one shows effort and is worth the buy. I cannot reccomend this game enough if you like platformers whether it be Sonic, Mario, Commander Keen,  previous Rayman titles etc. 

It's a great co-op and solo game and don't worry unlike the New Super Mario Bros games, you do not bounce off eachother, you actually have moves to help. You can slap one another ...but, if used right it can actually save your butt. 

It's worth noting both Rayman Legends and Origin are worth having together, there are SOME levels from Origins you unlock in Legends. But there's a lot of fun to have with both- so get on it! 

DRM NOTE:
This game requires Uplay to launch, which is incredibly irritating. On top of steam a mini-Uplay client needs to boot and often you'll find yourself waiting for Uplay to update before you get a chance to play your game. This counter productive move really ruins the whole idea of steam keeping games up to date when Ubisofts -DRM ontop of DRM- has to update seperately so it can triple check you're not a thief. This is of course is only highlighing my frustration when you know there's pirates playing this who do not have to sit through any of this and just enjoy the game that they didn't pay for but I did.

10049561.review:
Rayman foi um jogo contemporâneo de Mario e Sonic, com a diferença de que cresceu na rede BBS, onde inicialmente era distribuído como shareware. Hoje em dia poucos jogos mantiveram esse estilo de plataforma, nem mesmo os maravilhosos jogos do Mario na Nintendo mantiveram o estilo, mas a produtora de Rayman quis manter e investiu nisso, daí tivemos o maravilhoso Rayman Origins e agora o Rayman Legends. Um jogo feito para agradar, história simples mas extremamente divertida com uma jogabilidade sensacional. É um jogo pra toda a família, da criança aos avós.

Se vc está cansado de jogos que investem abusivamente em gráficos e tiroteios sem fim mas não entregam um mínimo de diversão, este jogo é pra vc. Divertido, dinâmico e difícil, sim, difícil, coisa rara de se ver nos jogos de hoje. Este não dúvida da inteligencia do jogador e entrega uma experiência de jogo pra não esquecer.

O jogo tem uma trilha sonora magnífica, utilizando músicas famosas com arranjos eletrônicos lembrando a era 16bits, com destaque para a fase extra que se desbloqueia ao fim do jogo que é toda voltada à música.

O único defeito deste jogo nem é dele é da ubisoft com seu uPlay, aquilo é terrível, tenebroso e ruim. Apenas a ubisoft nã ose deu conta de que seu "client" é ruim (qume tem duvidas quanto a isso, basta digitar no google uplay e irão ver).

Este é um jogo que deveria inspirar outras produtoras, além de ser inspirador para o jogador. 
Se tem dúvidas de comprar, não tenha mais, é um ótimo jogo, um ótimo produto.

9966602.review:
Empolgante, desafiador e em muitos aspectos ainda melhor que o anterior, Rayman Legend é um dos melhores jogos de plataforma da atualidade. Novamente, o jogo não trás nenhum enredo, mas mantém a possibilidade de se jogar a campanha inteira em modo cooperativo, além de trazer um painel de desafios online para que os jogadores possam competir entre si.

O jogo trás várias mecânicas novas, que são muito mais práticas e intuitivas que as do jogo anterior, além de permitir uma variedade maior de situações. 

Desta vez os personagens já começam o jogo com todas as suas habilidades, ao invés de receber uma por nível e existem muito mais personagens diferenciados que podem ser liberados em fases bônus ou por lumens (espécie de moeda do jogo).

Uma coisa legal, é que ao atingir determinada pontuação em alguma fase, o jogador receber um cartão da sorte que ao raspar, pode desbloquear criaturas novas, tokens para desbloquear fases e até mesmo fases do Rayman Origins refeitas com os novos gráficos e mecânicas!

Outro grande destaque vai para as fases musicais, em que é preciso fazer os movimentos do personagem de acordo com o ritmo da música, sob pena de morte certa rs! As fases são realmente muito interessantes.

Enfim, é um excelente jogo de plataforma, divertido e com uma linda arte cartunizada. As animações entre as transições de fases e ao final de cada chefe são muito engraçadas. Recomendo pra qualquer um que goste do estilo, mas para aqueles que gostam de jogar com a família, é praticamente obrigatório. MUITO BOM (8/10).

9944933.review:
Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.

Gameplay: Rayman Origins was a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. Rayman Legends is a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. It's the same "old-school" platforming experience delivered in Rayman Origins, but this time it's delivered just a bit better. Gone are some of the absolutely infuriating and sometimes unfair memorization-heavy levels (for the most part; I'll get to that later). Out of the core five worlds, there were really only three levels that I wasn't too terribly fond of. For a game that has about 40 levels in the core worlds, that's quite good. In fact, my only "minor-major" complaint about the core worlds is the implementation of Murphy. It shows that he was meant for the Wii U version, but it's not that much of a deal breaker; just that it maybe could've been handled in a slightly better manner (let's say controlling Murphy with the right analog stick). 

Note that I signified the fact that the ratio of good to bad levels was quite good in the core worlds. There is also a portion of the game called "Back to Origins," which is essentially a best-of collection of levels from Rayman Origins. Again, most of these levels are pretty good, but it just seems lazy to me to only bring back some of the levels, rather than bring back all of them. They've essentially given us all of the good stuff, leaving us no reason to go out and buy Origins. Much to my annoyance, they also brought back the boss fights from Origins, which are the aforementioned unfair memorization-heavy levels. They were the worst part of Origins in my opinion, but they are not the worst part in this game.

That "honor" goes to the Livid Dead Party world, which in my opinion contains some of the worst levels in the game. The Land of the Livid Dead level from Origins was easily my favorite level in the entire game, so you can imagine my disappointment when I found that all that was new and Livid Dead related was another music stage. It wasn't bad, but it was still very disappointing. Then... the remixes strike. These are 8-Bit reprises of the music stages that you unlock at the end of each world, with the two primary differences being a lack of checkpoints and an (in my opinion) incredibly stupid and infuriating visual filter(s). The first stage wasn't so bad; it just kinda hurt my head since it was a fisheye lens. The second stage... made me not want to 100% the game, even though I had gotten 682 Teensies up to that level. I don't get motion sickness, but that stage nearly made me throw up about three times due to the godawful visual filter done exclusively for "LAWLZ RETRO GUIZ." The rest of the stages were more of the same, albeit not nearly as bad as the second remix stage.

Again, despite my negativity, I will wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who anyone who just wants a pure fun platforming experience. Just stick with 100%ing the core worlds; the rest of the game ain't worth it. For an incredibly well crafted and fun set of core levels, a mediocre way of padding out the gameplay, and an immensely disappointing Livid Dead world, I will give this game an 8.5/10 for gameplay.

Story: Skipping this, as the story can literally be told in less than a paragraph.

Graphics: Man, I wish Ubisoft would release the level creator/editing tool to the public so that we can do things with it. Then again, maybe it's for the best that they don't; it'd only be a matter of time until the Internet poops all over such a glorious utility. What I'm trying to say is that this game is gorgeous and that we (as consumers) should totally be able to get our hands on the editor to make more amazing stuff happen. The character design is quite good as well, if some of the characters start to look like the others after a while. Despite this, there's a great deal of characters that you can switch between, so that you're not stuck staring at the same character the entire game. For proving yet again that style trumps number of polygons, this game gets a 5/5 for graphics.

Music: You can tell that the composers had a great deal of fun with the music in this game. That fun of composing transcribes into additional fun in playing the game. It's not something that most people would want to listen to outside of the game (at least I'd think so), but it's still very fitting and lends itself quite nicely to the ambiance of the stages. The songs chosen for the music stages puts this soundtrack over the top, allowing it to receive a 5/5 for the music portion.

Overall score of 8.5/0/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. If I didn't decide to be a completionist for this game, I would've rated it higher; however, the Livid Dead Party is still a pretty large blemish on an otherwise excellent game. Again, the best experience is achieved by just sticking to the core five worlds in my opinion.

9886477.review:
Rayman Legends is a must have if you; enjoy sidscrolling platformers, played Rayman Origins and liked it or you are a fan of the Rayman franchise.

First of all, the art style is outstanding! I was amazed after playing Origins as it just looks beautiful. Everything is very unique and have very smooth animations with each boss being 3D but looking like they are still 2D.
Secondly, the sounds and music are amazing with comedic sound effects for hitting enemies and great music that suites each atmosphere very well.

The level design is very well done with many challenging and gorgeous looking levels you won't get bored, with levels filled with secrets normally hard to get to, intense boss battles, fast paced music based levels and difficult time trials. There is also a extra area containing levels from Rayman Origins with the new art style and new lum system.

The game also supports controllers and allows up to 4 players locally, unfortunately like Origins there is no online co-op support, although it does have a daily and weekly challenge which has online leaderboards and gives you prizes depending on how high you were in the leaderboards.

The length of the game is hard to say but as you can see I have played quite a bit of it and still have not got everything with there being 700 teensies to collect and the addicting challenges you will pump hours into this game, if you do have people to play locally with then there is a game mode called 'Kung Foot' which is a football game where you have a very small area to play with 2 teams. The ball is very bouncy and can be hit all over the place making it very chaotic and fun. Although there is a lot to do once you do it all and collect everything you most likely won't play it an awful lot after although you may replay after a year or so or if you have a friend to play it with again.

Some improvements from Origins stand out other than the extended gameplay and improved art style which is that they removed the annoying thing where enemies turned into bubbles on death, although the player bubble death is there which isn't a bad thing. The lums have also been improved making it so the first lum in a row of lums is purple/pink and if collected will give 2 lums and will pass onto the next lum unless a yellow one is collected making collecting the lums in order more important and can be challenging when they moving around. The amount of collectables has also been increased.

Lastly, the characters in the game are similar to the ones in Origins just with a few more reskins but also the addition of the princess-barbarians which wield an axe as a weapon the first one being Barbara which each need to be rescued. Although there are many characters the reskins are very minor for the princesses mainly.

Overall I highly recommend buying this game it is certainly worth it full price, one problem people may have is that it is run through uPlay which means you need to make a uPlay account as well and can sometimes be a problem for people. I was very pleased with pre-ordering this game for £25 which also got me Rayman Origins free with it.

9845182.review:
This is the best platformer I have ever played. Take everything great about Rayman Origins and make it even better. All the great stage design, boss fights, and challenging difficulty is back. There is so much content in this installment of the Rayman series. Online challenges, remastered Rayman Origins stages, Local Co-Op mode with a fun minigame, Time Trials, creatures to collect, characters to unlock and a ton of awesomely designed stages in the main section of the game. There is also a nice statistics screen to keep track of all your progress.

There are online challenges that change on a daily and weekly basis. Every player in the world competes in them and gets ranked by how well they perform in the challenge. You can also race against the better ranked player's ghosts. It basically shows exactly what they did during the challenge, while you are playing. You can also increase your trophy level by placing high in lots of challenges and clearing portions of the game. 

The music themed stages in this game are probably my favorite platforming levels in any game ever. Playing a whole level in sync with the music feels very satisfying. There are also a ton of other stages that are amazingly designed. The boss fights are very satisifying to play. The Time Trials portions of stages feel perfectly designed for running through them as fast as you can. There is quite a bit of depth in making your character move as fast as possible in all situations. These Time Trials make you realize how fast you can actually go.

I have spent around 40 hours to 100% the game and do some of the online challenges. You can probably spend around 30 hours just to 100% the game and around 20 hours trying to complete the levels. Some of the levels are very hard and the online challenges have sections that are even harder. They bring back portions of the Land of the Livid Dead from Rayman Origins for some of the online challenges. You can also play a lot of the Rayman Origins levels in this game, but they have been remastered to make the levels a bit better designed. 

This game has everything you could want in a platformer. It is highly recommended and I don't think you can find a better designed platformer game than this one. Go buy it now!

9814859.review: Every time I play this game, I'm just amazed at the amount of the love, care and attention that was so clearly poured into it. Every single level - and there's TONNES, even before you consider the fact that many (all?) of Rayman Origins' brilliant levels are also included - all have their own personality, and you're never left feeling like the game is just going through the motions. The music-themed levels that cap each of the game's worlds are an absolute highlight - if platforming set to a mariachi cover of Eye of the Tiger doesn't whet your whistle, I'm not sure what else I could possibly say. Suffice to say, I want this game to last forever, and I'm reviewing it with the sole purpose of hopefully convincing others to try it as well. One of the best games of the last decade, and one of the best plaformers of all time.

9812734.review:
Rayman Legends is a fun, addictive game, that improves upon the originals with slightly improved graphics using the beautiful UbiArt Engine. The level design as well music are fantastic, A few shortcoming held it back from completle greatness, but I still thorougly enjoyed it.

Foremost, the interesting level design really shines with the varied levels that you have to overcome. The goals is always the same if not slight different. Rescue a certain number of teensies by finding the secret rooms as well as scouring the level for invisible walls and areas . The journey is accomplishing this and there is nothing better then finding them all  and getting 100% on the level. Other levels of interest are the boss levels as well as the timed ones that keep the variety up. Continuing on, the music levels that you find at the end of each area in the game are fabulous and are always something to look forward to as well as challenging in their own right. Lastly, the simple fair gameplay and tight controls. Everything required for a great platformer. Xbox controller is what I used and what I would recommend althought I'm sure keyboard works fine.

For the negatives I wouldn't really say they are complete negatives, but something that people like me will have to learn to live with. There is a lot of online/leaderboard type integration. There are dailies and weeklies. They are indeed fun and definetly challenging. By doing them you are rewarded with lums which are used for unlocking differnt characters in the game that you can play as.The majority can be unlocked just by beating the game but there are a few that require you to do them for awhile. Although I have no idea if these characters are worth the effort or if there mere recolors they are considered superior in terms of cost and I would assume they are pretty good. The positives of this is there is added gametime to the game as well as a stretch goal if you really enjoy it. The negative is not everything is unlocked right after beating the game which means you were probably wont go back unless you really are dedicated. Definetly the most frustrating thing would have to be the Back to Origins levels. While all the good levels in the original Rayman Origins are included they are not unlocked right away. You will unlock all of them sometime after you've beaten the game which means you cant play them in their original order until then. This is extremely frustating as after you beat the final boss and done the extra world the last thing you want to do is go back and 100% those levels that you have done before if you played the original. It would of been a lot better if they were unlocked in order after beating each area of the main game. At the very least I am happy they are included in game as extra content and I applaud the devolopers for not making someone purchase Rayman Legends if they want to experience it.

Kind of ranted on about the negatives, but I figure people know or have heard about how great is and should hear a different side. Definetly worth the puchase!

8.5/10

9739036.review:
This game is simply AMAZING. Absolutely fantastic. This is EXACTLY how you make a sequel to a good game!

Firstly, the artwork of the game is just like Rayman Origins, only there's a lot more detail going on here to make the colors and art style mesh a bit more together. That being said, the artwork is beautiful and despite the main characters' very colorful, silly appearance, the settings and areas match them so well that it's hard to say that they feel out of place. The music is just as good, and also brings a more thematic feel to the game, seeing as how Legends takes a bit more of a civilization styled world as opposed to the open wilderness areas that Origins featured. The soundtrack fits each world nicely, nailing a variety of genres and styles almost perfectly. My only complaints with the music would be the oddly off-putting Invasion level songs, which don't seem as urgent as they're supposed to feel.

As a modern platformer game, the amount of levels in the game is extremely important, and Legends most certainly didn't disappoint. There's TONS of levels in the game spanning over five unique worlds, and for those who dearly miss the content from Rayman: Origins, there's 60 levels from Origins included in the game to satisfy both crowds. Legends' levels also add a bit more challenge to the levels which partly secures my previous complaint on the easiness of Origins' levels. Though some levels still did feel a bit too easy, I feel the challenge is still decent in the game for what it was going for; a game to please both casual and hardcore players.

The amount of unlockables in the game is a great deal more than Origins, but it is a bit lacking. Once you've unlocked all of the normal levels, and the Origins levels, the only other things to get include costumes for the four main characters, though they aren't that special as many of the costumes follow a set theme with each of the characters, such as a Knight costume for Rayman and Globox, a Caveman costume for the Teensies, Rayman and Globox, a Dark Rayman and Dark Globox costume, etc. As far as the methods to unlock them go, it all depends on how much you've played the game as most of the costumes are locked behind a set amount of Lums collected to unlock them, going all the way up to 1 million lums for the final Rayman costume. Collecting all 700 Teensies also rewards you with a costume, which I think is pretty underwhelming. Though the Warrior Princess characters are just different costumes for Barbara, I do like the different amounts of variety in clothing, hair styles and colors they use with each of them. It's a nice touch and they at least added more than 2 extra costumes for Rayman this time.

The game plays very fluently, the controls are very well thought out and easy to use, so most of the gameplay is reliant on the player's skill. I've never felt like any death in the game was on part of bad level design or poor control design as they're damn good. I would recommend that people play the game with a gamepad though as playing with the keyboard can get a bit awkward.

Speaking of level design and levels, the way they presented the levels in each of the worlds was fantastic. Although each world spanned across at least 10 different paintings that counted as levels, I felt as though I was transitioning from one part of the world's story to the next. Additionally I will say that each world seems to have it's own story, rather than seeming like each world is connected somehow. It makes it seem like each world is separate from the others moreso than just in setting and appearance and gives the game some actual life and a sense of freedom and adventure despite being in a large tent with a bunch of old, crusty paintings.

My absolute favorite part of this game that got me hyped were the ingenious music levels, where every action int he level is set to the beat and rhythm of a song, remixed in a very special way for each world's music level. Though there's only a handful of music levels in the game, I feel like this isn't a bad thing as each music level plays out fantastically. The look of sheer joy on my face when I realized that the song playing in the level Castle Rock was a Rayman style remix of "Black Betty" is something I can never forget. And although the music levels are seen as the biggest selling point of Rayman Legends, Ubisoft went the extra mile to ensure that they put effort in all of the levels, and used the music levels as a lure for players, which makes the game that much richer in the experience.

In terms of story, I'm willing to forgive Rayman Legends for its very basic storyline. Rayman games never exactly had a great story to them, and the fact that there's no set canon of the Rayman games just adds to the charm, which this game is chock full of. The basic goal of the game seems to intertwine itself with the individual stories that come along with each of the worlds.

The Challenges and Kung Foot modes of the game add a bit more of a competitive side to Rayman Legends. Competing in different challenges every day and week for a chance to be seen at the top of the leaderboards is very nice, but I feel the PC version's Challenge mode is sort of sullied with the rise of many cheaters, especially in timed Challenges. I don't consider timed Challenges of any sort to be very serious on the PC version as people just cheat to get sub 10-second times as opposed to the people who actually have skill and talent in the game. Lum collection and Distance endurance challenges are just fine though as it's very hard to seem like one's cheating at these challenges as they can be done at one's own pace.

I don't have any experience with Kung Foot though as I haven't had the chance to play this game with multiple people.

In conclusion, this game is absolutely fantastic. Rayman Legends is a damn good example of how to make an excellent sequel to a good game. Legends builds upon the foundation and base of the original Rayman Origins and addresses many other issues that Origins had and aims very high to correct them. I would certainly say that Rayman Legends is much better than Origins, despite Origins also being an excellent game in its own right.

Oh, as an additional warning, you have to make a separate U-Play account in order to play the game from Steam, which I honestly find annoying and a little pointless.

Overall I'd give this game a 10/10

9681283.review:
Ubisoft - доказала, что не умеет делать плохих игр! 10/10
Rayman Legends просто неприлично богат контентом! Множество уровней. Каждая картина отличается художественным подходом, что радует глаз. Правда! Каждый уровень просто великолен! Если проходить игру на 100%, то она становится ещё лучше, потому что мы собираем всё что есть, всех малюток, всех lums... Получается мы исследуем мир ещё более тщательней. А сама сложность возрастает.
Например, сначала мы просто проходим уровень(обычный), а после нам дают уровень, где надо на время добежать да ещё и по пути собрать всех малюток. После нам могут дать уровень с боссом. А в конце каждой картины есть музыкальный уровень - это просто супер, чтобы пройти его с первого раза надо в темп всё делать, один неправильный шаг и всё.
Ещё про уровни, они настолько красиво нарисованы, и настолько детализированы, что улыбка до ушей не спадает до конца игры!
В Rayman Legends есть одна картина, где всё выполнено в 8 бит. Воу! Как там круто и сложно, это надо только видеть, я не знаю что будет с вашими глазами после прохождения, но свой фан вы точно получити. Ubisoft любят эту тематику, как Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon доказал это, так и эпичная "картина".
 Rayman Legends - подарит вам такую радость, что хватил ещё надолго :)

9676230.review: Если сказать, что это просто платформер, то это значит сказать ничего. Rayman® Legends это лучший платформер.))

한때 어린시절 플레이스테이션1으로 고독의 난이도 였던 레이맨을 즐겼던 사람으로써 정말로 추억이기도 하고.

유비 소프트 특유의 독특한 디자인과 다양한 에피소드들도 흥미를 끌기 다양하고.특히 전작 오리진 시리즈 보다 박진감 넘치게 플레이가 가능해서 좋았습니다 특히 일부 스테이지에서는 음악에 맞춰 액션들을 하는 인터페이스는 정말 색다르다고 봅니다.

9661172.review:
I feel that there is only one way to describe this game: classic.

The controls are nice and tight. Levels are a blast. Character and environment designs are whimsical and quirky. It's sometimes challenging, but not in the nail-biting "Dark Souls" way but in the "whoops I messed up that move, let's keep going cause this is fun" kind of way. Overall, the feel of the game makes you just want to keep playing and playing.

It's just really, really fun. I would definitely consider this a huge step up from Rayman Origins, which is also a pretty phenomenal game, though I think this game makes Origin obsolete since it includes unlockable remastered Origin levels.

A side note, the pop culture references this game makes are pretty amusing. The swimming levels are pretty much a throwback to Crash Bandicoot: Warped's scuba diving levels (too bad they control just as badly with a keyboard though, but tbh I haven't really seen that many "aqua combat" sequences in games that were actually fun). Also, the guys behind this game must have either really loved or hated Dreamwork's How to Train Your Dragon movie, hahaha.
