1360461.review:
You know, it's funny. Rayman was once considered "just another platform game" but now with Sonic running underwhelming sequels and Mario failing to do anything new or creative since Mario Galaxy, it's Rayman whose ultimately on top and destroying them with what is hands down one of the best examples of a platform game in over a decade.

The first thing you'll notice about Rayman is the atmosphere. With beautiful hand-drawn artwork and polish that is truly unrivaled, the game gives off an immediate great first impression. Fortunately it doesn't stop there.

Lead by great music and fantastic level design, Rayman Legends manages to snag your attention and hold on to it for dear life. Constantly changing things up, every world adds new concepts and eases them in with an old-school "learn by doing" approach.

With that said, it should be said that this game can get very hard. It starts out easy but very quickly ramps things up. This is of course expected of a Rayman game and wouldn't be one without being as punishing as it is beautiful.

And the best part of it all is... content. The game has a ton of it and it all holds up to the same level of quality. If you're even the slightest bit interested, you'd be a fool not to buy it. Easily my game of the year for 2013.

1430969.review:
One of the best games of 2013, if not the best platformer. 
Every square inch of this game oozes heart, soul, charm, and whimsy.

The sheer amount of content puts many other games to shame: want to play single player? It's there. Want to obsessively collect items and trinkets? They're in there, but not in a way that makes it tedious. Want to play a simple yet hilariously competative multiplayer game? Kung-Foot, the Shaolin Soccer simulator you always wanted is in there. Want a single player platformer with tight controls, great physics, amazing art and incredible music and sound design? It's there. Want to play the same with four players? You can do that too. Want daily and weekly challenges that you can play time and again to top the charts and compete against your friends? It's there.

There is way too much to do and way too much fun to be had. If you missed out on Rayman Origins, just get Legends as it even includes updated versions of the best levels from Rayman Origins that you can play! It really does have it all!

If you like platformers, this game is a no-brainer. It is a complete and total upgrade to Rayman Origins, which is a great game itself. Pretty much everything that could have been improved, has been improved. The controls are really tight and I never encountered frustating or unfair passages in the game. The new cover songs-themed levels are really enjoyable and satisfying as well and I really wish the game had more of those. If you are not sure about buying the game, get Rayman Origins instead. It gives you a good idea of the game mechanics and it's a bit cheaper.
However, Rayman Origins is not required to enjoy Legends, because there is no continuous story across games and a decent amount of levels from Origins are available to play in Legends.

694065.review: I simply cannot reccomend this game enough! In fact, this game reminded me of the exact reason why I got into video games in the first place. It is just pure fun and amazement, constantly showing innovative and creative ideas. Every single level adds something new to the table and the mechanics are refined and polished. The reward system is great as well, giving you the incentive to keep on trying for that high score, or trophy, or extra levels. It's a simple shame that this game does not have any steam support (besides launching in Uplay, a terrible DRM system by ubisoft) so I cannot see all the many achievments I would have wracked up. However there is a sort of online vs play with scores, and if you enjoyed a game like dustforce for that aspect I could see you enjoying this as well. Bottom line is: buy it for single player or buy it for multiplayer, but if you like sidescrolling platformers, fun action, and incredible visuals and music there is no reason for you not to have this game.

1379702.review:
WARNING: uplay DRM, may the creators of it burn in hell.

I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).

And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.

All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Its's generally much easier than Origins (which apprached Super Meat Boy levels at times) but better balanced and still immensely fun. It would definitely be worth it at full price so at this price it's a steal. Play it!

Jogabilidade muito fluída, com excelente level design e cenários lindos.

Se divirta com o bom co-op local, os desafios diários e semanais e os easter eggs espalhados pelo jogo. Até os sons são bem detalhados.

O menu em galeria faz jus: Rayman Legends é uma verdadeira obra de arte.

Le jeu de plates-formes 2D ultime.
Des niveaux et des défis à la pelle avec une réalisation technique et artistique à la perfection. De nombreux devs devraient prendre exemple.
On a un jeu très rythmé avec de l'action et des niveaus très speed qui demandent de l'adresse, des réflexes et beaucoup de skill, on se rapproche de Super Meat Boy dans ce domaine.
Bien que ce jeu ai l'air enfantin et coloré, la difficulté et le challenge sont au rendez-vous et il est désormais possible de comparer ses stats en lignes.
Au final Mario parait vieux, usé et fatigué, bon pour la retraite.

6439521.review:
Cartoon graphic? Yes gimme!

A worthy sequel to Rayman Origins, a true blast playing the game. Despite the uPlay plaguing the game, but I'll turn blind eye just because the game's bloody awesome.

Still maintaining the old Rayman mechanic. You jump, you punch, you run. Some of the mechanic is truly comical for example using your partner to tickle the enemy so he raises the spike shield so you can hit it till dead. Welp, only in Rayman maybe.

I also like the daily challenges where you compete with other players as 'ghosts' to beat a series of... challenges. From collecting items as fast as possible, to clearing enemies in a screen. Frankly this provides a new end game for players that have beaten the game - and it's a cool thing to have.

Level designs are just neat. Well yes, cartoon, but who cares. All designs are just perfectly blend together. There are varying degrees of levels' difficulties that require you to time, mostly jumping from platform to platform to collect gold rings/items, but it doesn't hit you with frustration. Regular enemies are mostly easy, you just need to be a bit more careful and don't get too excited to finish a level to actually smash the enemies with your Rayman body not punch. Ew.

Performance wise, I'm running the game with my weaker VGA and it runs silky smooth. No question asked, no complaint, unlike many games nowadays that require patches (and the excuse of 'so many hardware configurations out there!'). Well done Ubisoft, well done.

So grab your controller, hit some bad guys and play this awesomesauce game now!
